questions.text:
You're a public health nurse working in a large city. Over the past few days, you've noticed a significant increase in patients presenting with similar symptoms at multiple clinics and hospitals:
1. High fever
2. Cough
3. Sore throat
4. Body aches
5. Fatigue
Which type of surveillance system would be most effective in rapidly identifying and tracking the potential outbreak suggested by this pattern of symptoms?
questions.solution:
Surveillance in Practice: There are three parallel systems of surveillance:

This system is in practice in India under Integrated Diseases Surveillance Project.

Topic: Basics of epidemiology, surveillance

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 8, Page no. 137

choices.text: No Vaccine should be given in this visit.
Only second dose of OPV is given.
2nd dose of Pentavalent, OPV, Rota, fIPV are given in this visit.
Mild infections are not a contraindication for vaccination.

questions.text: A 12-week-old boy was brought to the health center today with complaints of mild cough. As per vaccination history, he received BCG, OPV at birth and only first dose of Pentavalent, OPV, Rota vaccine, fIPV vaccine, pneumococcal conjugate vaccine before 6 weeks. Which of the statement is true regarding vaccination of this case?
questions.solution:
Vaccines are generally safe, but it's crucial to check for contraindications to prevent serious reactions. For instance, if someone has a severe allergy to a vaccine or its components, they should avoid it. Additionally, immune-deficient children should not receive live vaccines to ensure their safety.

Topic: Epidemiology and vaccine

Reference: K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 3, Page No. 131

questions.text: A study was carried out to find out the association of exposure to metal fumes on respiratory morbidity among industrial workers, 200 workers having respiratory morbidity and 400 workers not having respiratory morbidity were studied. In both these groups, 100 of them had a history of being exposed to metal fumes. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
This study is a case-control study. In a case-control study, individuals with a specific outcome (cases) are compared to those without the outcome (controls) with respect to their exposure to certain factors. In this scenario:

Cases: 200 workers with respiratory morbidity

Controls: 400 workers without respiratory morbidity

Exposure: 100 workers in both the case and control groups had a history of being exposed to metal fumes.

The study compares the exposure history between workers with and without respiratory morbidity. It does not follow individuals over time (cohort study) or assess the prevalence of exposure and outcome at a single point in time (cross-sectional study). It focuses on the association between exposure to metal fumes and the presence of respiratory morbidity, making it a case-control study.

Features

  • Both exposure and outcome have occurred before the start of the study
  • Study proceeds backward from effect to cause
  • Uses a control group to support an inference

Steps

  • Selection of cases
    • definition of case
    • source of case
  • Selection of control
  • Matching
  • Measurement of exposure
  • Analysis
    • a. Cohort study: A cohort study follows a group of individuals over time to observe the development of outcomes. In a cohort study, individuals are classified based on their exposure status, and their health outcomes are monitored. In this scenario, the study design is not following individuals over time; instead, it's comparing individuals with respiratory morbidity (cases) to those without (controls) based on their exposure history. Therefore, it is not a cohort study.
    • c. Cross-sectional: A cross-sectional study assesses exposure and outcome simultaneously at a single point in time. It captures a snapshot of the population at a specific moment. In this case, the study compares workers with respiratory morbidity to those without, but it doesn't provide information about the temporal sequence of exposure and outcome. It's looking at the exposure history and respiratory morbidity status at a specific point, making it more fitting for a case-control design.
    • d. RCT(Randomized Controlled Trial): Randomized Controlled Trials involve random allocation of participants to different interventions, and outcomes are observed over time. This study does not involve randomization or interventions; it's purely observational, comparing exposure in workers with and without respiratory morbidity. Therefore, it is not an RCT.

Topic: Epidemiology and vaccine

questions.text: Anonymous group is supporting group used mainly in drug dependance to
questions.solution:
Newer initiatives:

  1. NIKSHAY :
    • TB surveillance using case based, web-based IT system
    • Central TB Division in collaboration with National Informatics Centre has undertaken the initiative to develop application named Nikshay.
    • combination of two Hindi words NI and KSHAY meaning eradication Of TB.
    • This software was launched in May 2012 and has following functional components:
      • Master management
      • User details
      • TB patient registration and details of diagnosis, DOT provider, HIV status follow-up, contact tracing, outcomes.
      • Details of solid and liquid culture and DST, LPA, CBNAAT details.
      • DR-TB patient registration with details.
      • Referral and transfer of patients.
      • Private health facility registration and TB notification.
      • Mobile application for TB notification.
      • SMS alerts to patients on registration,
      • SMS alerts to programme officers.
      • Automated periodic reports:
        • Case finding
        • Sputum conversion
        • Treatment outcome.
        • The programme has started using IT enabled adherence tools like 99 DOTS for HIV-TB patients. This will be expanded to all TB patients with implementation of daily regimen
  2. TB Notification
    • In order to ensure proper diagnosis and management of TB cases and reduce TB transmission and the emergence and spread of MDR-TB, it is essential to have complete information of all TB cases.
    • It is now mandatory for all healthcare providers to notify every TB case to local authorities every month in a given format.
  3. Ban on TB Serology
    • The serological tests are based on antibody response, which is highly variable in TB and may reflect remote infection rather than active disease.
    • Currently available serological tests are having poor specificity and should not be used for the diagnosis of pulmonary or extra-pulmonary TB. Their import, manufacturing. sale, distribution and use is banned by the Government of India.
  4. Direct benefit transfer schemes
    • Direct beneficiary transfer systems are being established by linking TB patients reported in NIKSHAY with AADHAR and PEMS to effectively deliver benefits to TB patients and their providers.

choices.text: India rank at 132 out of 189 countries
From south Asian region India ranked 3rd after Sri-Lanka and Maldives

questions.text: All of the following statements about Human development index are true except
questions.solution:
The human development index is also a composite index. It combines indicators representing three dimensions:

  1. Longevity: Life expectancy at birth
  2. Knowledge: Expected years of schooling and mean years of schooling
  3. Income: Gross national income (GNI) per capita in purchasing power parity (PPP) in US dollars.

These three are the basic dimensions of human development.

  • Values range between 0 and 1. It allows for international comparison.
  • HDI of India is 633 (rank 132 out of 189 countries) (Human Development Report, UNDP 2022)
  • Norway has HDI of 0.961 which is ranked 2nd (Human Development Report, UNDR 2022)
  • Switzerland has HDI 0.962 which is ranked 1st (Human Development Report, UNDR 2022)
  • From South Asian region India ranked 3rd after Sri Lanka and Maldives.

Topic: Concept of Health and disease, Human development index

Reference: UNDP (United Nations Development Programme). 2022. Human Development Report 2021-22: Uncertain Times, Unsettled Lives: Shaping our Future in a Transforming World. New York, Page no. 24

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 3, Page no. 19

questions.text: A 60-year-old Rajubhai with a history of smoking develops a persistent cough and shortness of breath. He is diagnosed with lung cancer. Now what level of prevention will you do?
questions.solution:
1. Primordial Prevention:
    • This level of prevention focuses on preventing the development of risk factors in the population to reduce the incidence of diseases.
    • aims to address the root causes of diseases.
    • In the case of lung cancer, this would involve preventing risk factors like smoking from emerging at the population level. However, Rajubhai has already developed lung cancer, so this level of prevention is not applicable.
  2. Primary Prevention:
    • This level aims to prevent the onset of a disease in individuals who are at risk but do not yet have the disease. (health promotion and specific protection)
    • Examples include vaccination and lifestyle modifications to prevent the development of a specific condition. Again, Rajubhai has already been diagnosed with lung cancer, so primary prevention is not the appropriate level in this case.
  3. Secondary Prevention:
    • This level is concerned with early detection and treatment of a disease in its preclinical or early clinical stages to prevent further progression.
    • Examples include regular screenings for cancer in asymptomatic individuals. In the case of Rajubhai, he has already developed symptoms (persistent cough and shortness of breath), indicating that the disease has progressed beyond the early stages. Therefore, secondary prevention is not the primary focus.
  4. Tertiary Prevention:
    • This level focuses on preventing the complications and progression of an established disease, improving the quality of life, and preventing disability. (Disability prevention and rehabilitation)
    • In the case of Rajubhai with a confirmed diagnosis of lung cancer, tertiary prevention would involve interventions such as medical treatments, surgery, chemotherapy, and supportive care to manage the disease, alleviate symptoms, and improve his overall well-being.

Topic: Concept of Health and disease, Types of prevalence

choices.text: Walk for 30 minutes at least 5 days a week, adding moderate-intensity activities like hiking on weekends.
Engage in vigorous-intensity activities like brisk running for 30 minutes, 3 days a week.
Should get involved In at least 60 minutes of moderate- to vigorous-intensity physical activity daily.
Limit physical activity due to her high blood pressure and pre-diabetes, focusing on rest and relaxation.

questions.text: Sarah, a 45-year-old teacher with a desk job, suffers from high blood pressure but loves going for weekend hikes. Her doctor recently confirmed that she is pre-diabetic. She wants to improve her health through physical activity but isn't sure how much is appropriate for her condition. Based on the WHO recommendations and Sarah's situation, which of the following physical activity plans is most suitable for her?
questions.solution:
WHO recommendations for 18-64 years:

Aim for at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic activity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity aerobic activity per week, or an equivalent combination of both. Additionally, do muscle-strengthening exercises (targeting all major muscle groups) on two or more non-consecutive days.

Sarah's conditions: While she has high blood pressure and pre-diabetes, physical activity is actually recommended for managing these conditions. Both moderate and vigorous intensity activities are appropriate for her age group, with adjustments in duration or intensity based on her own tolerance and doctor's advice.

Topic: National health programme, NCD

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 5, Page no. 52

questions.text: Imagine you're a public health researcher studying the prevalence of vaccine-preventable diseases in a rural community. For that you Recruit a team of healthcare workers to actively visit households and conduct surveys and physical examinations to identify potential cases. which type of surveillance is this?
questions.solution:
Active surveillance: As described in the scenario, you're proactively sending a team of healthcare workers to visit households and conduct surveys and examinations to identify potential cases. This initiative involves actively searching for cases, which is the defining characteristic of active surveillance.

Passive surveillance: This type of surveillance relies on healthcare providers and other sources to passively report suspected cases based on established criteria. They don't actively seek out potential cases.

Sentinel surveillance: This focuses on collecting data from specific representative sites or populations (e.g., select clinics, schools). While it can provide valuable insights, it doesn't cover the entire community like your active approach.

Behavioral surveillance: This gathers information on behaviors and risk factors associated with health outcomes, often through surveys or interviews. While relevant to understanding disease spread, it doesn't directly identify cases the way your active approach does.

Therefore, actively sending a team to identify potential cases through surveys and examinations falls under the category of active surveillance in this context.

Topic: Concept of Health and disease

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 8, Page no. 137

questions.text: Which of the following mortality measures is expressed as a rate per 1,000 population per year?
questions.solution:
The crude death rate is indeed the only option expressed as a rate per 1,000 population per year.

Here's a why the other options are not expressed as rates:

Case-fatality rate: This is a proportion expressed as a percentage or per 100 cases, indicating the proportion of individuals with a specific disease who die from that disease.

Proportional mortality ratio: This is a ratio comparing the proportion of deaths from a specific cause within a group to the proportion of deaths from that cause in the whole population.

Standardized mortality ratio (SMR): This is a ratio comparing the observed number of deaths in a specific group to the number expected based on age-specific death rates of a reference population.

Table: Category of epidemiological parameters.

Topic: Basics of epidemiology

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 9, Page no. 143

questions.text: A medical college admitted 150 students in a year, with 100 males and 50 females. So what will be the sex ratio (females per 1,000 males) in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Here's how to calculate the sex ratio:

Divide the number of females by the number of males: 50 females / 100 males = 0.5

Multiply the result by 1,000 to express the ratio as females per 1,000 males: 0.5 * 1,000 = 500

Therefore, the sex ratio in this scenario is 500 females per 1,000 males. This means that for every 1,000 male students, there are 500 female students.

Topic: Basics of epidemiology

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 9, Page no. 143

questions.text: Imagine you're a dentist conducting a research study. You're interested in understanding the rate of new cavities forming in children's teeth. You follow 10 children for 2 years, and during that time, you identify a total of 15 new cavities. What is the incidence density of dental caries in this group of children (expressed as cavities per 100 person-months)?
questions.solution:
Incidence density = (Number of new events/(Person - time)) * 100

To calculate Person-time/person-months,

= multiply the number of children by the follow-up duration in months

= Total child-months follow-up = 6 +12+ 8 + 18 + 12+ 24+ 18 +12 + 16+24 =150

So, Person-time/person-months=150

The incidence density is (15 new cavities / 150 person-months) * 100 = 10 cavities per 100 person-months.

Topic: Basics of epidemiology

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 9, Page no. 144

questions.text: In a cancer unit of a hospital, 40 women with breast cancer were followed up for 5 years after undergoing surgical treatment. At the end of the 5-year period, 24 of these women were still alive. What is the 5-year survival rate for the women with breast cancer in this study?
questions.solution:
Calculation: To calculate the survival rate, we need to divide the number of women who survived 5 years (24) by the total number of women in the study (40) and multiply by 100 to express it as a percentage:

Survival rate = (number of patients alive five years after diagnosis or initiation of therapy / Total number) x 100

= (24 / 40) x 100

= 0.6 x 100

= 60%

Survival rate: Survival rate, despite being a death measure, often gauges cancer treatment effectiveness. If a patient survives 5 years after diagnosis or therapy, it's generally seen as a positive sign. These rates estimate future survival by applying them to current populations, painting a hypothetical picture of life expectancy at various ages. Life table are computed from survival rates applying current survival rate to the population as of now.

Topic: Basics of epidemiology

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 9, Page no. 147

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT the best indicator of health care delivery?
questions.solution:
Health care delivery indicators: The frequently used indicators of health care delivery are:

  • Doctor-population ratio
  • Doctor-nurse ratio
  • Population-bed ratio
  • Population per health/subcentre, and
  • Population per traditional birth attendant.

These indicators reflect the equity of distribution of health resources in different parts of the country, and of the provision of health care.

Explanations of Each Option:

  1. Doctor-population ratio: This measures the availability of doctors for a given population size. A lower ratio indicates fewer doctors per person, potentially impacting access to care. This is a valid indicator of healthcare delivery.
  2. Doctor-patient ratio: This refers to the average number of patients a doctor sees in a specific timeframe. While it reflects workload and potentially wait times, it doesn't directly measure overall healthcare availability. Therefore, it's not the best indicator compared to others.
  3. Population-bed ratio: This measures the number of people per available hospital bed. A higher ratio signifies potential bed shortages and difficulties accessing in-patient care. This is a valid indicator of healthcare delivery.
  4. Population per health/sub-centre: This indicates the number of people served by a primary healthcare facility. A higher ratio implies limited reach of basic care services in the area. This is a valid indicator of healthcare delivery.

Topic: Concept of Health and disease

questions.text:
A remote island is facing a unique public health challenge. An isolated infectious agent has been identified, posing a threat to the local population. In response, the government decides to implement a comprehensive intervention plan to completely eliminate the infectious agent and prevent any future occurrences.
What is the primary goal of the public policy intervention described in the scenario?
questions.solution:
A) Elimination: Elimination refers to reducing the incidence of a disease to zero in a defined geographical area. In this scenario, the goal is not merely to reduce the incidence within the island but to completely eliminate the infectious agent.

B) Extinction: Extinction involves the complete eradication of a species or, in this case, the infectious agent. The intervention aims to eliminate the infectious agent from the island entirely, making this the correct answer.

C) Eradication: Eradication is the deliberate and permanent reduction to zero of the worldwide incidence of a disease caused by a specific agent. While the intervention in this scenario is comprehensive, the goal is specific to the island, not on a global scale.

D) Quarantine: Quarantine involves isolating and restricting the movement of individuals who may have been exposed to an infectious agent. While quarantine may be part of the intervention, the primary goal in this scenario is the complete elimination of the infectious agent.

Reference: IAPSM, 2nd Edition, Chapter 8, Page no. 129

questions.text: An attribute or exposure that is significantly associated with the development of a disease is known as:
questions.solution:
Here's why the other options are not as accurate:

b) Agent factor: This term is more specific to infectious diseases, referring to the pathogen or organism that causes the disease. While some risk factors are indeed agents, not all are (e.g., smoking, family history).

  • The first link in the chain of disease transmission is a is defined as a disease agent.
  • The disease "agent" substance, living or non-living, or a force, tangible or intangible, the excessive presence or relative lack of which may initiate or perpetuate a disease process.
  • A disease may have a single agent, a number of independent alternative agents or a complex of two or more factors whose combined presence is essential for the development of the disease.

c) Host factor: This refers to any characteristic of the individual that makes them more susceptible to a disease, such as genetics or pre-existing conditions. While risk factors can include host factors, they can also be external (e.g., environmental exposures).

  • In epidemiology, the human host is metaphorically termed "soil," and the disease agent as "seed."
  • Host factors influencing disease outcomes can be categorized into demographic, biological, social and economic, and lifestyle characteristics.
  • This classification, including factors like age, genetics, socio-economic status, and lifestyle choices, helps identify associations between specific host traits and diseases, providing valuable insights into the root causes of health conditions.

d)Environmental factor: This term encompasses any external factor that can increase disease risk, such as pollution, diet, or lifestyle choices. While many risk factors are environmental, some are not (e.g., genetic mutations).

Topic: Concept of Health and disease

Reference: K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 2, Page No. 44

choices.text: The point of no return for a disease
The threshold for seeking medical attention
The boundary between clinical and subclinical disease
The level of funding needed for disease control

questions.text: What does the "waterline" in the iceberg analogy represent?
questions.solution:
A concept closely related to the spectrum of disease is the concept of the iceberg phenomenon of disease.

The floating tip of the iceberg represents what the physician sees in the community, i.e., clinical cases.

The vast submerged portion of the iceberg represents the hidden mass of disease, i.e., latent, inapparent, presymptomatic and undiagnosed cases and carriers in the community.

The "waterline" represents the demarcation between apparent and inapparent disease.

In some diseases (e.g., hypertension, diabetes, anaemia, malnutrition, mental illness) the unknown morbidity (i.e., the submerged portion of the iceberg) far exceeds the known morbidity.

The hidden part of the iceberg thus constitutes an important, undiagnosed reservoir of infection or disease in the community, and its detection and control is a challenge to modern techniques in preventive medicine.

One of the major deterrents in the study of chronic diseases of unknown aetiology is the absence of methods to detect the subclinical state — the bottom of the iceberg.

Diseases which do not show iceberg phenomenon are

  • Measles
  • Rubella
  • Rabies
  • Tetanus

Topic: Concept of Health and disease, Iceberg phenomenon

Reference: K. Park, 27th Edition, Chapter 2, Page No. 46

questions.text: True regarding stroke in ICD-11?
questions.solution:
ICD-II (INTERNATIONAL CLASSIFICATION OF DISEASES)

  • ICD-11 is designed for the 21st century and reflects the significant progress in science and medicine over the past 30 years.
  • Revised every 10 years, right now 11th edition released in June 2018.
  • It is designed for use with digital health applications and systems.
  • It is free to access online in multiple languages.
  • It includes over 55,000 entities, including diseases, disorders, injuries, etc.
  • It includes 120,000 clinical terms with millions of codable terms.
  • It has new categories and updated classification schemes.
  • It supersedes the outdated ICD-10.
  • It has a new chapter on sexual health, which includes gender incongruence.
  • It has a new chapter on traditional medicine.
  • It reclassifies stroke as a neurological disorder.
  • It contains 3 Volumes and has 26 chapters along with chapter X, V.
    • I Volume: Tabulation list
    • II Volume: Reference guide
    • III Volume: Alphabetical Index
    • Chapter X: Extension quotes
    • Chapter V: Functional assessment
    • Chapter 6: Mental behavioural and Neurodevelopmental disorders
    • Chapter 26: Traditional medicine
    • Chapter 21: Disease of unknown aetiology

Topic: Concept of Health and disease, ICD-11
